{{about|the entire Boise State athletic department|the football program|Boise State Broncos football}} {{Infobox college athletics | logo = Boise State Broncos Logo.svg | logo_width = 150 | name = Boise State Broncos | university = [[Boise State University]] | conference = [[Mountain West Conference]]{{wrap}} [[Pacific-12 Conference|Pac-12 Conference]] (Wrestling){{wrap}} ''Independent'' (Women's Gymnastics) | division = [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] | director = Mark Coyle | city = Boise | state = Idaho | stateabb = ID | teams = 17 | stadium = [[Bronco Stadium]] (c. 33,500, Blue [[FieldTurf]]) | arena = [[Taco Bell Arena]] (c. 12,820) | mascot = [[Buster Bronco (Boise State)|Buster Bronco]] | nickname = [[Broncos]] | color1 = Orange | hex1 = ff7f00 | color2 = Blue | hex2 = 0000ff | pageurl = http://www.broncosports.com/ | pagename = Broncosports.com }} The '''Boise State Broncos''' are the official athletic program of [[Boise State University]]. The Broncos compete in a wide variety of sports. Perhaps the most well-known of these sports is the football program. The program attained a 13-0 season in 2006 capped by a memorable overtime win in the [[2007 Fiesta Bowl]] against the [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooners]]. They finished the season as the only major undefeated college football team, yet they became the first team since the 2004-2005 season with an unblemished record to not receive any share of the National Championship. Other notable sports teams include the wrestling team, which competes in the [[Pacific 12 Conference]], the women's basketball team, which won the WAC for the first time ever in 2007 and the [[Boise State Broncos tennis|tennis teams]] which have consistently had nationally ranked players. The Broncos have a very successful athletic program overall, winning the WAC commissioner's cup for the 2005-06 year and 2009-10 year.
The school's football stadium, [[Bronco Stadium]], is famous for its use of a unique blue colored [[artificial turf]] (specifically [[FieldTurf]]) field, instead of traditional green.
